comments.author: DrBeer
comments.body: Great description, but I have a question. How is the withdrawal or conversion of the Black Money (BM) token to fiat implemented?Without the possibility of interacting with fiat, for the majority, such a system does not make sense, because. you can use quite standard tools available on the market. For example, crypto wallets, which are already enough on the market. I will not list - so as not to create "unlawful advertising" But in principle, such wallets already have everything that you have listed, plus there is multicurrency.Accordingly, the question arises - what is the competitive advantage of this system against the background of advanced crypto wallets?

comments.author: BlackMoney
comments.body: One of the most interesting features of our platform is BlackMoney digital codes. They are a set of Latin letters that can be created and redeemed.A similar system has been used on some infamous crypto exchanges and has proven to be very user-friendly.You can just leave funds in your wallet, or you can create a code, transfer it to a friend, he will pay and receive funds to his balance.A very convenient tool for paying salaries to employees, paying for orders for amounts pegged to dollars, or simply storing currency in this form.You can create a code, write it down on a piece of paper, come back after 5 years, create a new account and safely activate the code.

comments.author: BlackMoney
comments.body: DrBeer, thank you for your interesting questions! Let me describe what exactly we are.Our token BM (From BlackMoney) is not a real crypto token or asset. As like you said, any project that offers any tokenshould ensure its value. But our system forwards some another goals. You should not use system to store your money for a long time.You should use it to fastly cut any connections between your transactions (incoming to system <---> outcoming), it is something like crypto-mixer,but not exactly, because it does not mixes any, it just takes your crypto and gives you another.Anyone should have their rights privacy, and it is our philosophy. And using our digital codes (that my translator badly translated to "kodos", I'm sorry, now I'll write here only with help of my native english speaking friend) you can simplytransfer your money to another user of our system. Its not a new token at all. It is just an alias for american dollars, and 1 BM always will be 100$. Why not using, like, USDT? To not to confuse some user about what exactly we are doing. If we were using USDT, some users may think that we are mixing their money.
